current_age) = max(10, 60 - 50) = 10total_months = time_horizon_years * 12 = 120Risk → Return mapping (annual):very_low: 5%low: 7%low_moderate: 8%moderate: 10%high_moderate: 11%high: 12%very_high: 14%monthly_return_r = annual_return / 12For this scenario (high): annual_return = 12% → monthly_return_r = 0.12 / 12 = 0.01Inflation default: 5.5% annually unless overridden.Do (Step-by-Step)Normalize inputs → emit goal_input_json.Refer “SIP Calculation” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Refer “Inflation Adjustment” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Refer “Recommendation Engine (Fund Category Types)” from SIPGoalPlannerAgent.Output allocation_plan_json (equity %, debt %, recommended categories, notes).Guideline risk for appetite:"guideline": {"very_low": "Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity","low": "Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity","low_moderate": "Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity","moderate": "Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt","high_moderate": "High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt","high": "High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt","very_high": "Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt"}Validation Hooks: Validate schema + percentages.Visualization (ReportGeneratorAgent):Pie chart → equity vs debtBar/graph → sub-categoriesStrictness: Never recommend fund names. Only fund categories.Schemasgoal_input_json{ "goal_type": string, "target_amount": number, "currency": "INR", "time_horizon_years": number, "total_months": number, "risk_appetite": string }inflation_adjusted_json{ "inflation_pct": number, "years": number, "unadjusted_target": number, "adjusted_target": number }sip_calc_json{ "monthly_return_r": number, "months_n": number, "adjusted_target": number, "monthly_sip": number, "status": "ok" | "error", "error": string | null }allocation_plan_json{"equity_percent": number,"debt_percent": number,"recommended_fund_categories": {"equity": string[],"debt": string[],"elss_optional": boolean},"notes": {"very_low": string,"low": string,"low_moderate": string,"moderate": string,"high_moderate": string,"high": string,"very_high": string}}Outputs RequiredEmit STRICT JSON (no prose, no markdown):goal_input_jsoninflation_adjusted_jsonsip_calc_jsonallocation_plan_json====================================================================Addendum – Mandatory Report Sections for SIP Reports====================================================================All orchestrations and plan graphs must ensure downstream agents(FormatterAgent, ReportGeneratorAgent, QAAgent) enforce the followingsections in the final comprehensive_report.html:1. I will follow the formulas and risk appetite mappings as defined in the prompt. Finally, I will generate the JSON outputs. I will also generate the sip_projection_table_json.

Read Today's Paper AMFI releases new stock categorization, cut-offs for largecap hiked to Rs 84,000 crore SECTIONS AMFI releases new stock categorization, cut-offs for largecap hiked to Rs 84,000 crore By Surbhi Khanna , ET Online Last Updated: Jul 05, 2024, 11:43:00 AM IST Rate Story Follow us Share Font Size Abc Small Abc Medium Abc Large Save Print Comment Synopsis AMFI updated market cap categories: large cap threshold at Rs 84,300 crore, mid cap at Rs 27,600 crore, effective till January 2025. Stocks moving: Hero Motocorp to large cap, SRF to mid cap. Small caps increased, including SRM Contractors. Aligned with Nuvama predictions; affects fund visibility, manager decisions, and reclassification, with limited immediate flow impacts. ETMarkets.com The Association of Mutual Funds in India ( AMFI ) on Thursday has officially released the market cap categorization which highlights the changes in large, mid and small cap . The large cap threshold now stands at Rs 84,300 crore up from Rs 67,000 crore in December 2023. Meanwhile, for the mid cap the cut-off has risen to Rs 27,600 crore compared to Rs 22,000 crore previously. The large cap which are the top 100 now represent 63.6% which is down from 64.4% in December 2023. The mid caps (101-250) now account for 18.2% indicating an uptick from 17.8% in December. The small caps (251 and beyond) make up around 18.2%, showing an increase from 17.8% in December. These changes have been perfectly in line with Nuvama Alternative predictions. Best MF to invest Looking for the best mutual funds to invest? Here are our recommendations. View Details The stocks which were mid caps and are now large cap include Hero Motocorp, Zydus Lifesciences, NHPC, BHEL , Bosch, JSW Energy, and Samvardhana Motherson. Around seven stocks will now be mid cap from large cap which includes SRF, ICICI Prudential Life, Polycab India, Marico, Berger Paints, SBI Cards, and ICICI Lombard. Some stocks like HUDCO , BSE, Hitachi Energy, Blue Star will now come under mid cap category which were earlier under small cap. On the other hand, stocks such as Relaxo Footwear, Piramal Enterprises, Vedant Fashions, Zee Entertainment, Sun TV Network, The Ramco Cement will now be classified as small caps from mid caps ear", 'images': [], 'rank': 3}, {'url': 'https://www.indmoney.com/blog/amfi-rejig-see-what-stocks-are-categorized-as-large-cap-mid-cap-and-small-cap', 'content': 'Just a moment... Enable JavaScript and cookies to continue', 'images': [], 'rank': 4}, {'url': 'https://stableinvestor.com/2024/01/amfi-marketcap-list-jan-jun-2024.html', 'content': '64.4% Largecap | 17.8% Midcap | 17.8% Smallcap - AMFI Marketcap List (for Jan-Jun 2024) - Stable Investor Skip to content Close Menu SEBI Registered Investment Advisor + Financial Planner (Fee Only) || India Search for: Search Twitter Facebook Stable Investor Financial Planning & Investment Advisory Menu Financial Planning Services Full Goal-based financial planning service HNI (Affluent) Portfolio Advisory Investment advisory for investor with large portfolios About About Dev (Stable Investor) Benefits of Fee-Only Advice in India Archives Contact Financial Planning Services HNI (Affluent) Portfolio Advisory SEBI Disclosures SEBI RIA Compliance & Complaints Data Investor Charter in respect of Investment Adviser (IA) Impersonation Alert Beware of Imposters! 64.4% Largecap | 17.8% Midcap | 17.8% Smallcap AMFI Marketcap List (for Jan-Jun 2024) by Dev Ashish January 4, 2024 January 4, 2024 Leave a comment AMFI has come out with the latest update (6-monthly) for its marketcap bucketing to identify largecap, midcaps and smallcap stocks in India for January June 2024 period (based on data up to 31st December 2023. To ensure that all equity schemes follow uniform definitions for defining large, mid, and small caps, the Securities and Exchanges Board of India (SEBI) has defined them as follows: Large-cap companies 1st to 100th company in terms of market cap Mid-cap companies 101st to 250th company in terms of market cap Small-cap companies 251st company onwards in terms of market cap This is the basic Difference Between Large Cap, Mid Cap, And Small Cap stocks. I crunched the numbers from the latest data ( link ). The following table summarizes it: Here is a simpler explanation of the table above: The top 100 stocks, which are called largecaps, now form 64.4% of the overall marketcap of all the Indian stocks. The midcap and smallcaps have 17.8% allocation each in the overall pie. Interestingly, the minimum marketcap needed now to qualify as a largecap is Rs 67,018 Cr. The same figure for midcaps is Rs 21,994 Cr. So compared to just a few years back, many midcaps are now size of yesteryear largecaps! A while back I wrote that whether it made sense for SEBI to widen definitions to increase the number of large and mid-cap stocks? May be it is an idea worth considering now given so much money (via SIP inflows) following just a few hundred stocks. final_report.detailed:
Let me think through this: Based on the allocation plan (T001), a 70/30 equity/debt split is desired, reflecting a high-risk appetite. The fund shortlist (T012) presents a limited selection of funds. 

**Equity Allocation (70%):**
Given the constraints, the following funds are recommended for the equity portion:
*   **UTI Aggressive Hybrid Fund Regular Plan-Growth (Hybrid):** This fund provides a blend of equity and debt, aligning with the aggressive risk appetite, offering a 5Y return of 19.04%.
*   **HSBC Large Cap Fund Direct-Growth (Large Cap):** Aligns directly with the recommended 'Large Cap' category and offers a 5Y return of 18.15%.

**Debt Allocation (30%):**
The following funds are recommended for the debt portion, considering their relatively short-term nature and returns:
*   **Bank of India Short Term Income Fund (Debt: Short Duration):** Providing a 1Y return of 9.95% p.a. offering shorter-term stability.
*   **Aditya Birla Sun Life US Treasury 1-3 year Bond ETFs FoF (Debt: International Debt):** Offering a 1Y return of 9.58% p.a., providing diversification by investing in US treasury bonds.

**Rationale:**
The selection prioritizes funds that align with the recommended equity and debt categories in the allocation plan. Return percentages are used as a simple comparative metric due to the lack of indicative ratings. The hybrid fund acts as an equity fund allocation given the lack of Small and Mid-Cap funds in the shortlist.

**Limitations:**
The fund shortlist is limited, lacking a strong selection of Mid-Cap and Small-Cap equity funds. Indicative ratings are missing, and the return percentages are used as a simplified metric. Furthermore, selecting only two debt funds concentrates the debt allocation significantly. The fund return percentages are not inflation-adjusted. There is a risk due to the concentration of funds overall and the limitation of selection.

**Recommendations:**
It is strongly recommended to retrieve data from fund-specific sources to obtain performance metrics, ratings, and expense ratios for a more thorough analysis. Expand the fund selection beyond the shortlist to include a wider range of options across all recommended categories, especially Mid-Cap and Small-Cap. Consider a tool/API that provides a larger and more varied list of Funds.

**Risk Factors and Uncertainties:**
The recommendations are based on a limited dataset and may not reflect a comprehensive view of the available investment options. Changes in market conditions and fund performance can significantly impact the actual returns and overall portfolio performance. The historical return data is not indicative of future performance. There is a concentration risk of only having a few funds in the recommendation.
recommendations: Retrieve data from fund-specific sources for comprehensive performance metrics and ratings.
Expand the fund selection beyond the shortlist.
Consider diversifying the debt portion of the portfolio with more funds.
Consult a financial advisor for personalized investment advice.
risks_or_warnings: The fund shortlist is limited, and these recommendations should be considered preliminary.
Historical return data is not indicative of future performance.
There is a risk of capital loss associated with investments in equity and debt funds.
Diversification is limited by the shortlist provided.
key_factors_considered: Alignment with allocation plan (70/30 equity/debt split)
Fund categories (Large Cap, Hybrid, Short Term Debt, International Debt)

T014.initial_thoughts: I need to validate the mathematical correctness of the SIP calculations, the asset allocation percentages, the non-emptiness of the fund shortlist, and the currency information in T001 and T013.  I will pay attention to potential division by zero errors in rate calculations. Also, I'll check if the allocation totals add up to 100%. Finally, I need to see if currency exists and if it's consistent across outputs, and whether fund_shortlist is empty before making recommendations. I also need to make sure the goal input json types are valid.

issues.problem: The monthly_return_r in sip_calc_json is given as 0.01, while the expected_annual_return is given as 12%. While 12%/12 = 1%, it's better to be explicit about the calculation to avoid confusion. Although not strictly an error, it introduces a potential point of misunderstanding.
issues.recommendation: Clarify the relationship between expected_annual_return and monthly_return_r in sip_calc_json, either by explicitly stating the division or deriving monthly_return_r directly.

issues.problem: Inflation rate is used to calculate the adjusted target amount in inflation_adjusted_json. However, the formula used is not explicitly stated. The adjusted target amount seems correct, but adding the formula will greatly increase confidence in the process and results.
issues.recommendation: Explicitly define and state the formula for calculating the adjusted target amount.

issues.problem: Although the asset allocation percentages in allocation_plan_json (equity_percent and debt_percent) sum up to 100%, this constraint is not explicitly validated in the agent's code.
issues.recommendation: Implement a check within the SIPGoalPlannerAgent to explicitly validate that equity_percent + debt_percent = 100 and log an error if it's not the case.

issues.problem: The agent recommends funds from a limited shortlist, and acknowledges these limitations in its 'final_report'. However, it still presents the chosen funds as recommendations without sufficient warning about data quality. The risk warnings are buried near the end of a long text, and don't appear in the summary.
issues.recommendation: Move risk caveats into the final_report summary, as well as the intro.  Emphasize that this is a preliminary assessment, and that data should be retrieved from fund-specific sources.

issues.problem: The task_completion_score of 0.85 implies the agent is aware of inadequacies. Surface the reasons for this score in the output.
issues.recommendation: Add an attribute like 'self_assessed_weaknesses' to surface the issues that led to the task_completion_score of 0.85.

output.validation_summary: The SIP calculations and asset allocation are mathematically sound, and the fund shortlist is not empty. Currency information is present. However, there are minor issues with clarity in the monthly return calculation, explicit validation of the allocation percentages, and prominence of the fund recommendation limitations. Fund allocator is glossing over deficiencies.

notes.very_low: Very Low policy → Extremely conservative, e.g., 90% debt / 10% equity
notes.low: Low policy → Conservative, e.g., 70% debt / 30% equity
notes.low_moderate: Low-Moderate policy → Tilted conservative, e.g., 60% debt / 40% equity
notes.moderate: Moderate policy → Balanced mix, e.g., 50% equity / 50% debt
notes.high_moderate: High-Moderate policy → Tilted aggressive, e.g., 60% equity / 40% debt
notes.high: High policy → Aggressive, e.g., 70% equity / 30% debt
notes.very_high: Very High policy → Extremely aggressive, e.g., 90% equity / 10% debt

Stocks moving: Hero Motocorp to large cap, SRF to mid cap. Small caps increased, including SRM Contractors. Aligned with Nuvama predictions; affects fund visibility, manager decisions, and reclassification, with limited immediate flow impacts. ETMarkets.com The Association of Mutual Funds in India ( AMFI ) on Thursday has officially released the market cap categorization which highlights the changes in large, mid and small cap . The large cap threshold now stands at Rs 84,300 crore up from Rs 67,000 crore in December 2023. Meanwhile, for the mid cap the cut-off has risen to Rs 27,600 crore compared to Rs 22,000 crore previously. The large cap which are the top 100 now represent 63.6% which is down from 64.4% in December 2023. The mid caps (101-250) now account for 18.2% indicating an uptick from 17.8% in December. The small caps (251 and beyond) make up around 18.2%, showing an increase from 17.8% in December. These changes have been perfectly in line with Nuvama Alternative predictions. Best MF to invest Looking for the best mutual funds to invest? Here are our recommendations. View Details The stocks which were mid caps and are now large cap include Hero Motocorp, Zydus Lifesciences, NHPC, BHEL , Bosch, JSW Energy, and Samvardhana Motherson. Around seven stocks will now be mid cap from large cap which includes SRF, ICICI Prudential Life, Polycab India, Marico, Berger Paints, SBI Cards, and ICICI Lombard. Some stocks like HUDCO , BSE, Hitachi Energy, Blue Star will now come under mid cap category which were earlier under small cap. On the other hand, stocks such as Relaxo Footwear, Piramal Enterprises, Vedant Fashions, Zee Entertainment, Sun TV Network, The Ramco Cement will now be classified as small caps from mid caps ear", 'images': [], 'rank': 3}, {'url': 'https://www.indmoney.com/blog/amfi-rejig-see-what-stocks-are-categorized-as-large-cap-mid-cap-and-small-cap', 'content': 'Just a moment... To ensure that all equity schemes follow uniform definitions for defining large, mid, and small caps, the Securities and Exchanges Board of India (SEBI) has defined them as follows: Large-cap companies 1st to 100th company in terms of market cap Mid-cap companies 101st to 250th company in terms of market cap Small-cap companies 251st company onwards in terms of market cap This is the basic Difference Between Large Cap, Mid Cap, And Small Cap stocks. I crunched the numbers from the latest data ( link ). The following table summarizes it: Here is a simpler explanation of the table above: The top 100 stocks, which are called largecaps, now form 64.4% of the overall marketcap of all the Indian stocks. The midcap and smallcaps have 17.8% allocation each in the overall pie. Interestingly, the minimum marketcap needed now to qualify as a largecap is Rs 67,018 Cr. The same figure for midcaps is Rs 21,994 Cr. So compared to just a few years back, many midcaps are now size of yesteryear largecaps! A while back I wrote that whether it made sense for SEBI to widen definitions to increase the number of large and mid-cap stocks? May be it is an idea worth considering now given so much money (via SIP inflows) following just a few hundred stocks. nodes.description: Reconcile fund shortlist with allocation categories and percentages from T001.
nodes.agent_prompt: Reconcile the fund shortlist generated in T012 with the allocation categories and percentages specified in T001's allocation_plan_json. Ensure that the selected funds align with the overall investment strategy and risk profile. Output the final fund recommendations with rationale.

initial_thoughts.entity_1: Let me think through this: The allocation_plan_json from T001 specifies a 70/30 equity/debt allocation for a high-risk appetite, with recommendations for Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap equity funds, and Short Term Debt and Corporate Bond debt funds. T012's fund_shortlist provides several funds with associated categories and notes.
initial_thoughts.entity_2: Let me think through this: I need to reconcile T001's allocation targets with the funds listed in T012, selecting funds that align with the recommended categories and considering their performance notes (e.g., 5Y Return, 1Y Return).
initial_thoughts.overall_observations: Let me think through this: The shortlist contains limited options for equity (only one explicit 'Large Cap' and one 'Hybrid' fund) and several debt fund options. I need to make recommendations based on the constraints while acknowledging the limited data and potential need for further refinement.

review_checklist.alignment_with_goal: Let me think through this: Did I accurately reconcile the allocation plan with the fund shortlist? Did I stay true to the original prompt's goal of fund recommendations with rationale?
review_checklist.what_was_missed: Let me think through this: Could I have extracted more relevant information from the fund notes (return percentages)?  Did I sufficiently address the limitations in the fund shortlist data?
review_checklist.risk_of_misleading: Let me think through this: Am I presenting the recommendations as definitive choices, or clearly acknowledging the data limitations? Could someone be misled by the limited selection?
review_checklist.improvement_opportunities: Let me think through this: Could I provide a better rationale for the selected funds, given the limited data? Can the output be structured more clearly for downstream agents?

final_report.summary: Fund recommendations aligned with a 70/30 equity/debt allocation, based on available fund categories and return data. Equity portion: UTI Aggressive Hybrid Fund, HSBC Large Cap Fund. Debt portion: Bank of India Short Term Income Fund, Aditya Birla Sun Life US Treasury 1-3 year Bond ETFs FoF.
final_report.detailed:
Let me think through this: Based on the allocation plan (T001), a 70/30 equity/debt split is desired, reflecting a high-risk appetite. The fund shortlist (T012) presents a limited selection of funds. 

**Equity Allocation (70%):**
Given the constraints, the following funds are recommended for the equity portion:
*   **UTI Aggressive Hybrid Fund Regular Plan-Growth (Hybrid):** This fund provides a blend of equity and debt, aligning with the aggressive risk appetite, offering a 5Y return of 19.04%.
*   **HSBC Large Cap Fund Direct-Growth (Large Cap):** Aligns directly with the recommended 'Large Cap' category and offers a 5Y return of 18.15%.

**Debt Allocation (30%):**
The following funds are recommended for the debt portion, considering their relatively short-term nature and returns:
*   **Bank of India Short Term Income Fund (Debt: Short Duration):** Providing a 1Y return of 9.95% p.a. offering shorter-term stability.
*   **Aditya Birla Sun Life US Treasury 1-3 year Bond ETFs FoF (Debt: International Debt):** Offering a 1Y return of 9.58% p.a., providing diversification by investing in US treasury bonds.

**Rationale:**
The selection prioritizes funds that align with the recommended equity and debt categories in the allocation plan. Return percentages are used as a simple comparative metric due to the lack of indicative ratings. The hybrid fund acts as an equity fund allocation given the lack of Small and Mid-Cap funds in the shortlist.

**Limitations:**
The fund shortlist is limited, lacking a strong selection of Mid-Cap and Small-Cap equity funds. Indicative ratings are missing, and the return percentages are used as a simplified metric. Furthermore, selecting only two debt funds concentrates the debt allocation significantly. The fund return percentages are not inflation-adjusted. There is a risk due to the concentration of funds overall and the limitation of selection.

**Recommendations:**
It is strongly recommended to retrieve data from fund-specific sources to obtain performance metrics, ratings, and expense ratios for a more thorough analysis. Expand the fund selection beyond the shortlist to include a wider range of options across all recommended categories, especially Mid-Cap and Small-Cap. Consider a tool/API that provides a larger and more varied list of Funds.

**Risk Factors and Uncertainties:**
The recommendations are based on a limited dataset and may not reflect a comprehensive view of the available investment options. Changes in market conditions and fund performance can significantly impact the actual returns and overall portfolio performance. The historical return data is not indicative of future performance. There is a concentration risk of only having a few funds in the recommendation.
recommendations: Retrieve data from fund-specific sources for comprehensive performance metrics and ratings.
Expand the fund selection beyond the shortlist.
Consider diversifying the debt portion of the portfolio with more funds.
Consult a financial advisor for personalized investment advice.
risks_or_warnings: The fund shortlist is limited, and these recommendations should be considered preliminary.
Historical return data is not indicative of future performance.
There is a risk of capital loss associated with investments in equity and debt funds.
Diversification is limited by the shortlist provided.
key_factors_considered: Alignment with allocation plan (70/30 equity/debt split)
Fund categories (Large Cap, Hybrid, Short Term Debt, International Debt)

nodes.description: Validate the math, allocation (ensure it equals 100%), shortlist (ensure it's non-empty), and currency presence from T001 and T013.
nodes.agent_prompt: Validate the mathematical correctness of the calculations performed in T001, ensure that the asset allocation percentages add up to 100%, verify that the fund shortlist generated in T013 is not empty, and confirm the presence and validity of the currency information. Output validation results.

output.initial_thoughts: I need to validate the mathematical correctness of the SIP calculations, the asset allocation percentages, the non-emptiness of the fund shortlist, and the currency information in T001 and T013.  I will pay attention to potential division by zero errors in rate calculations. Also, I'll check if the allocation totals add up to 100%. Finally, I need to see if currency exists and if it's consistent across outputs, and whether fund_shortlist is empty before making recommendations. I also need to make sure the goal input json types are valid.

issues.problem: The monthly_return_r in sip_calc_json is given as 0.01, while the expected_annual_return is given as 12%. While 12%/12 = 1%, it's better to be explicit about the calculation to avoid confusion. Although not strictly an error, it introduces a potential point of misunderstanding.
issues.recommendation: Clarify the relationship between expected_annual_return and monthly_return_r in sip_calc_json, either by explicitly stating the division or deriving monthly_return_r directly.

issues.problem: Inflation rate is used to calculate the adjusted target amount in inflation_adjusted_json. However, the formula used is not explicitly stated. The adjusted target amount seems correct, but adding the formula will greatly increase confidence in the process and results.
issues.recommendation: Explicitly define and state the formula for calculating the adjusted target amount.

issues.problem: Although the asset allocation percentages in allocation_plan_json (equity_percent and debt_percent) sum up to 100%, this constraint is not explicitly validated in the agent's code.
issues.recommendation: Implement a check within the SIPGoalPlannerAgent to explicitly validate that equity_percent + debt_percent = 100 and log an error if it's not the case.

issues.problem: The agent recommends funds from a limited shortlist, and acknowledges these limitations in its 'final_report'. However, it still presents the chosen funds as recommendations without sufficient warning about data quality. The risk warnings are buried near the end of a long text, and don't appear in the summary.
issues.recommendation: Move risk caveats into the final_report summary, as well as the intro.  Emphasize that this is a preliminary assessment, and that data should be retrieved from fund-specific sources.

issues.problem: The task_completion_score of 0.85 implies the agent is aware of inadequacies. Surface the reasons for this score in the output.
issues.recommendation: Add an attribute like 'self_assessed_weaknesses' to surface the issues that led to the task_completion_score of 0.85.

output.validation_summary: The SIP calculations and asset allocation are mathematically sound, and the fund shortlist is not empty. Currency information is present. However, there are minor issues with clarity in the monthly return calculation, explicit validation of the allocation percentages, and prominence of the fund recommendation limitations. Fund allocator is glossing over deficiencies.
